'''Mose John Allison, Jr.''' (born November 11, 1927) is an [[United States|American]] [[Jazz piano|jazz blues pianist]] and [[singer]].

==Biography==
Allison was born outside [[Tippo, Mississippi]] on his grandfather's farm, which was known as The Island "because Tippo Bayou encircles it."<ref name="bluesaccess">{{cite web | url=http://www.bluesaccess.com/No_33/mose.html | date=Spring 1998 | title=Mose Allison | publisher=Blues Access | accessdate=2014-03-04 }}</ref> He took piano lessons from age five,<ref>http://www.jazzwax.com/2010/09/interview-mose-allison-part-1.html</ref> picked cotton, played [[piano]] in grammar school and [[trumpet]] in [[high school]],<ref name="feather">Feather, Leonard & Gitler, Ira (2007) ''The Biographical Encyclopedia of Jazz'' Oxford University Press, p. 14</ref> and wrote his first song at age thirteen.<ref>http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=125065807</ref><ref>http://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2010/12/mose-d29.html</ref> He went to college at the [[University of Mississippi]] for a while, then enlisted in the U.S. Army for two years.<ref name="jazzwax">{{cite web | url=http://www.jazzwax.com/2010/09/interview-mose-allison-part-1.html | date=2010-09-09 | last=Myers | first=Mark | title=Interview: Mose Allison (Part 1) accessdate=2014-03-04 }}</ref> Shortly after [[Muster (military)|mustering]] out, he enrolled at [[Louisiana State University]], from which he was graduated in 1952 with a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in [[English studies|English]] with a [[Academic minor|minor]] in [[Philosophy]].<ref>Dickerson, James L. (2005). [[Mojo Triangle]]:Birthplace of Country, Blues, Jazz and Rock 'n' Roll (Schirmer Trade Books), pp. 110-112</ref>

In 1956 he moved to [[New York City]] and launched his jazz career performing with artists such as [[Stan Getz]], [[Gerry Mulligan]], [[Al Cohn]], [[Zoot Sims]], and [[Phil Woods]].<ref name="feather" /> His debut album, ''Back Country Suite'', was issued on the [[Prestige Records|Prestige]] label in 1957. He formed his own trio in 1958.

It was not until 1963 that his record label allowed him to release an album entirely of vocals. Entitled ''Mose Allison Sings'', it was a collection of songs that paid tribute to artists of the [[Mojo Triangle]]: [[Sonny Boy Williamson II|Sonny Boy Williamson]] ("Eyesight to the Blind"), [[Jimmy Rogers]] ("That's All Right") and [[Willie Dixon]] ("[[The Seventh Son (song)|The Seventh Son]]"). However, it was an original composition in the album that brought him the most attention – "[[Parchman Farm (song)|Parchman Farm]]". For more than two decades, "Parchman Farm" was his most requested song. He dropped it from his playlist in the 1980s because some critics felt it was politically incorrect. Allison explained to ''[[Nine-O-One Network Magazine]]'': "I don't do the cotton sack songs much anymore. You go to the Mississippi Delta and there are no cotton sacks. It's all machines and chemicals."<ref>901 Interview (May 1987), ''Nine-O-One Network Magazine'', p. 6</ref> 

Prestige Records tried to market Allison as a pop star, but Columbia Records and later Atlantic Records tried to market him as a blues artist. Because he sang blues, ''Jet'' magazine thought that he was black and wanted to interview him.<ref name="npr">{{cite web | url=http://www.npr.org/programs/jazzprofiles/archive/allison.html | title=Jazz Profiles from NPR: Mose Allison | publisher=NPR | accessdate=2014-03-04 }}</ref>

Allison was inducted into the [[Long Island Music Hall of Fame]] in 2006.

Allison's March 2010 album, ''The Way of the World'', "marked his return to the recording studio after a 12-year absence."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://moseallison.com | date=2010 | title=Mose Allison Official Web Site | accessdate=2014-03-03 }}</ref>

In 2012, Allison was honored with a blues marker on the Mississippi Blues Trail in his hometown of Tippo.<ref>http://www.msbluestrail.org/blues-trail-markers/mose-allison</ref> On January 14, 2013, Allison was honored as a Jazz Master by the National Endowment for the Arts at a ceremony at Lincoln Center in New York. The NEA Jazz Masters Fellowship is the nation's highest honor in jazz.<ref>http://arts.gov/honors/jazz/jmCMS/master.php?id=2013_01&type=bio</ref>

Allison has written some 150 songs.<ref>http://www.jazzwax.com/2010/09/interview-mose-allison-part-1.html</ref> His own performances have been described as "delivered in a casual conversational way with a melodic southern accented tone that has a pitch and range ideally suited to his idiosyncratic phrasing, laconic approach and ironic sense of humour."<ref>http://www.propergandaonline.com/in-depth-mose-allison/</ref>

==Influence==
Allison's music has influenced many [[blues]] and [[rock music|rock]] artists, including [[Jimi Hendrix]], [[The Rolling Stones]], [[Tom Waits]], [[The Yardbirds]], [[John Mayall]], [[J. J. Cale]], [[The Who]] (who made "Young Man Blues" a staple of their live performances), and [[Georgie Fame]], who described him, at a concert at the Rose Theatre Kingston on 24 May 2013, as "more important than Bob Dylan". [[Blue Cheer]] also recorded a version of his song "[[Parchman Farm (song)|Parchman Farm]]" on their debut album, as well as the band [[Cactus (band)|Cactus]], featuring [[Carmine Appice]] and [[Tim Bogert]] in the very early seventies. [[The Yardbirds]] and [[The Misunderstood]] both recorded versions of his song "I'm Not Talking".  

His song "Look Here" was covered by [[The Clash]] on their album ''[[Sandinista!]]''. [[Leon Russell]] covered Allison's song "Smashed!" on his album ''Stop All That Jazz''. [[Van Morrison]] released an album of his songs entitled ''[[Tell Me Something: The Songs of Mose Allison]]'', and [[Elvis Costello]] recorded "Everybody's Cryin' Mercy" on his album ''[[Kojak Variety]]'' and "Your Mind Is On Vacation" on ''[[King of America]]'' (Bonus Tracks). [[Dani Klein]] of Belgian music act [[Vaya Con Dios (band)|Vaya Con Dios]] recorded ''Mind on Vacation'' on the album ''[[Roots and Wings (Vaya Con Dios album)|Roots and Wings]]''.

[[Frank Black]] of the [[Pixies]] claims that the song "Allison" from the album ''[[Bossanova]]'' is about Mose Allison.<ref name="alec">[http://aleceiffel.free.fr/titles.html AlecEiffel.net Pixies Titles/Names]. Retrieved on 2008-04-01. {{WebCite|url=http://www.webcitation.org/5PwKtpADl|date =2007-06-28}}</ref> He also states this at the beginning of the video for the song. His song "Monsters of the Id" was recorded by [[Stan Ridgway]] on his 2004 album ''Snakebite: Blacktop Ballads And Fugitive Songs''.  

The film ''[[The Whole Nine Yards (film)|The Whole Nine Yards]]'' begins with Allison's song "I Don't Worry About a Thing" during the opening credits. [[Americana (music)|Americana]] [[singer-songwriter]] [[Greg Brown (folk musician)|Greg Brown]] wrote and performed the song "Mose Allison Played Here" on his 1997 album, ''Slant 6 Mind''.

==Personal life==
Mose married his wife Audre in 1949.<ref>http://www.charlestoncitypaper.com/charleston/mose-allison-doesnt-let-it-go-to-his-head/Content?oid=4004202</ref> They live on Long Island, where they raised four children, including daughter Amy, a musician.<ref>http://moseallison.com/?page_id=70</ref> His wife has said that, when she first met him, "I could tell that he was someone who generated his own joy."<ref>http://itsallpink.com/stories/373-30</ref> She has also said that "Mose has always paid attention to what is happening in the world, and has always read voraciously both past and present histories".<ref>http://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2010/12/mose-d29.html</ref>

==Political and cultural views==
Allison is reported to have strong views about 'the domination of money over everything, the growing lack of empathy on the part of the powers-that-be for the population, wars and more wars, and an underlying hypocrisy in society'<ref>http://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2010/12/mose-d29.html</ref> and the arrogance of colonisers of the Americas.<ref>http://www.charlestoncitypaper.com/charleston/mose-allison-doesnt-let-it-go-to-his-head/Content?oid=4004202</ref>
